div.head: THE DISEASE OF THE AGE.
div.p: Dr. C. W. Saleeby, who is such a fascinating writer on scientific matters, has just published through Cassells & volume of the deepest in terest, entitled "Worry: The Disease of the Age" (6s.). In this he points out the significance, the consequences, and the cures of worry, and in so doing he touches on a wide range of subjects of vital importance to the public well-being. All interested in religious and social questions will find the book most informative and suggestive.

"To worry is to miss the purpose of one's being," Dr. Saleeby boldly declares. "It is to fail--to fail for self, to fail for others, and it is to fail gratnitously. But the blunder is universal, and it is the characteristic symptom of an age which I believe to be the greatest in human history hitherto. To the evolutionist no other belief is open."

"What has not been sufficiently recognised is the importance of worry, not merely in itself as implying the absence of happiness, but as the cause of ills far greater than itselfthe cause predisposing to disease which would otherwise have been escaped altogether... As man becomes more self-conscious, and therefore more human, so he becomes more liable to that disease of the mind which is certainly unique in this respect, that alone of all human diseases there is no analogy to it whatever in the case of any of the lower animals. :.. Nowadays many cannot stand the psychical strain. They are injured partly by fatigue, partly by worry. It is a proved and accepted physiological truth that the adult is much more gravely injured by worry than by fatigue. Hence our nerve doctors are kept busy. Hence the incessant discovery of new nervous diseases."

Dr. Saleeby does not believe that mere mental overwork ever killed or injured anybody. "Brain work in a stuffy room will kill you of tuberculosis ; brain work plus worry has killed thousands, brain work plus worry, plus in. somnia many thousands more ; but if the brain work had been omitted, the impure air or the worry and the consequent loss of sleep would have had just the same result." But Dr. Saleeby points out that insanity is in no small measure a consequence of worry. Farther, "the consequences of worry in relation to ordinary physical disease are familiar to every physician. Not a few non-infectious diseases are known which seem frequently to be predisposed to be worry. Among these are gout, diabetes, and a certain form of goitre."

The many ways in which worry manifests itself is shown in a succession of chapters deal. ing with worry in illness; worry and boredom; worry, drugs and drink; worry, and action ; worry in childhood ; domestic worry; worry and old age ; worry and sex; the psychology of worry. And all these are full of striking illustrations.
In writing of "Worry and Disease," Dr. Saleeby says:

The piles of crutches at Lourdes indicate real cures of real diseases. The cures wrought by Christian Science are real cures. Faith| healing is a fact. Neither faith nor Mrs. Eddy can remove mountains - or kill a bacillus-but mind can act on mind. Terrible maladies exist which the united wisdom of every physician on the earth might be impotent to affect, but which would yield instantly and finally to the nonsensical jabbering of an immoral imbecile if only the patient's mind were affected thereby. These are scientific facts, as certain and as, important as the infectiousness of cholera, the germ causation of tuberculosis, or the triumphs of Listerian surgery.
In another place, speaking of Christian Science, he says :

If proof of the power of the mind in relation to hysteria and all forms of fanctional nervons disease be desired, the mere progress of Christian Science will provide it. Christian Science is increasing, and is even threatening, as Mark Twain declares, to become the dominant religion, because it meets a real need. It teaches that to worry and to fear must be attributed all the ills that flesh is heir to. And this is true of such an amazing proportion of these ills that Christian Science cures them. The religion that has this kind of survival value will survive.

One of the worries peculiar to our own time is due to our thought of the future of the race. "No idea of a duty to posterity, no recognition of the fact that the present is not only the child of the past but also the parent of the future, played much part in the thoughts of our ancestors." The writer says he has no space for an essay on "Anxious Patriotism and Worried Patriots," but he does point out that "concern about the future of the race is not merely a form of worry new to our time, nor yet is it merely a new and elevated form of moral sentiment; it is a force that makes for action. ... Our children's chilIren will rise up and call us blessed; this rery generation will be remembered as the irst which consciously and deliberately made he future its own highest concern,"

div.head: Alexandria Harbour,
div.p: The black and white chequered can buoy moored to the eastward of the Abattoir break water, has been removed and will not be again replaced.

div.head: Tir Espagnol.
div.p: The Alexandria Police have obtained & conviction from the Native Courts against the Tir Espagnol by the Cairo Railway Terminus its a "jeu d'hazard."

div.head: Another Soaffolding Acoident,
div.p: . Greek carpenter working at Boulac fell from the scaffolding of a house in course of construction and expired immediately from the effects of the fall.

div.head: H.M.S. "Diana".
div.p: H.M.S. "Diana" left Alexandria this morning for Port Said, where she will spend one day and take in coal, after which she will visit the ports of Syria and Cyprus.

div.head: The Windsor Hotel.
div.p: There was a meeting this morning of the board of directors of the Windsor Hotel (Egypt) Limited to decide on the plans of the new building for the Windsor Hotel and Casino

div.head: The New Alhambra.
div.p: The opening of the new Alhambra theatre, and consequently the début of the Lombardo troupe with the "Geisha," has been postponed from tomorrow until Wednesday evening. The box office is expected to be opened tomorrow.

div.head: Buried Alive.
div.p: On Friday last a native in the act of excavating loam from a bank at Helouan, was overwhelmed by a heavy fall of the embankment. On his being rescued he was found to be still breathing, but was conveyed to the hospit in a serious condition.

div.head: Roumanian Maritime Service
div.p: The quarantine imposed in Turkey against arrivals from Egypt having been increased by 24 hours, thus making a total of 72 hours, the departure of mail-boat "Regele Carol I" will also be advanced 24 hours, and will therefore take place to-morrow at 7 p.m.

div.head: Sir R. Slatin Interviewed.
div.p: A representative of Reuter's Agency has had and interview with General Sir Rudolf Slatin, Inspector-Generalof the Sudan, who is on a short visit to London. Speaking of the situation in the Sudan, he said that the position of affairs was entirely satisfactory, financially and politically.

div.head: Raid on Hashish Den.
div.p: On Friday night last the police raided a hashish den in the Coptic bazaar, the property of an English subject named Yussef Balsano. Thirty six hashish smokers were placed under arrest and the usual procèsverbal was drawn up against the owner of the premises.

div.head: Alexandria Breakwater.
div.p: The decision as to the construction of a breakwater in the East Harbour has been postponed until the autumn when it will be considered by the Municipality. The official reports of Mr. Malavel and Mr. Lloyd Davies have been completed and have been put before the Municipality.

div.head: The Tourah Case.
div.p: The Council of Discipline held at the Cairo Gouvernorat in connection with the charge against the Mamour of Tourah prison which has been the subject of so much comment in the press recently, heard finally the evidence of Moberley Bey, on Saturday last, and the accused, Commandant Ziady, was acquitted.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways,
div.p: We are officially authorised to contradict the report appearing in several of our contemporaries that Captain Hall, Traffic Manager of the Egyptian State Railways, is about to proceed to Europe for the purpose of studying the season ticket rates at present in operation on the different railways. This report, we are informed, is totally incorrect.

div.head: Lake Karoun's Denizens.
div.p: At the last meeting of the Zoological Society of London, Mr. C. L. Boulenger exhibited and made remarks on a new Hydromedusan, for which he proposed the name Murisia lyonsi, and of which examples of both polyp and medusa stages were obtained by Dr. C nington and himself during their recent exploration of Lake Karoun in the Fayum.

div.head: The · Tebtunis Papyri".
div.p: The second part of the " Tebtunis Papyri, The second part of the " Tebtunis Papyri," edited by Dr. B. P. Grenfell and Dr. A. S. Hunt; with the assistance of Prof. E. J. Goodspeed, of Chicago, will be published by Mr. Henry Frowde during this month. It deals with papyri found in the houses of Tebtunis, most of the documents belonging to the first three centuries of the Christian era. An important literary fragment is that of the lost Greek original of Dictys Cretensis.

div.head: Anoient Greek MS. Discovered.
div.p: The learning of the ancient Greeks has not yet after 2,000 years yielded up the last of its secrets. It is claimed for a Danish scientist, M. Heiberg, that he has quite recently discovered in a palimpsest in Constantinople a bitherto unknown work on mathematics by Archimedes. The MS., which is entitled "On Method," and is dedicated to Eratosthenes, relates (says the "Globe") to the applying of mechanics to the solution of certain problems in geometry. To be brief, there is in this ancient Greek MS., developed with remarkable boldness, a method that may be said to bear a strong resemblance to the integral calculus of onr modern days, and capable of being used for the solution of problems reserved for the genius of Leibnitz and Newton eighteen centuries later.

div.head:
THE FINANCIAL CRISIS.
BOURSE AND BANKING COMPANY OF EGYPT LIMITED.
div.p: An extraordinary meeting of the members of the Alexandria Stock and Sharebrokers Association was held in the Reading Room of the Alexandria Borrse this morning. The proceedings began at 11.40 o'clock and lasted three quarters of an hour: A large number of the members of the Association were present as the affairs of this company have attracted a great deal of attention. The committee was formed as follows: Messrs. Clement Suares, Chairman, Alfred Nabman, E. Mercinier, who represented the firm of Arditi, Dimitri Caralli, Alfred Salinas, F. B. Rossano and Victor Levi, members. Mr. Clement Suares opened the meeting and stated that he had received a petition signed by the majority of the meinbers of the Association, dated 22nd June last, wherein it was stated that owing to the peculiar position of the Egyptian market in the present crisis it was necessary to safeguard the collective interests. Accordingly on that date the commmittee of the Alexandria Bourse decided to Suspend operations in dealing in the shares of the company in question. The petitioners were in favour of regulating the dealings in the following way. All transactions at £1 and over were to be considered valid without delivery of the shares, and the value of the shares was to be considered as being actually on a basis of £1. Transactions under £1 were to be treated at the price made without delivery of shares. The chairman then asked if anyone present wished to make any remarks. Mr. Rodocanachi said that he was willing to abide by the conditions laid down in the petition, he was ready to lose what he had lost, but he could not allow others to 'benefit thereby. He suggested that the profits realised should be lumped together. Mr. Nahmann said it was impossible to exactly ascertain the individual position of each person. He remarked that very few persons would profit by the arrangement. The chairman then asked Mr. Rodocanachi not to persist in bringing forward a motion and in consequence of further explanations from Mr. Nahman, Mr. Rodocanachi gave way. Mr. Rossano next suggested that the delivery of the shares should not take place until six months hence. He said that if the public interested were not in agreement, and if the shares were delivered now, their clients could insist on a settlement by presenting their shares. We brokers are, he said, doing a favour to the Company by our policy and the Company ought to show its gratitude to us by witholding the shares for from three to six months. Mr. Nahman said that if legal proceedings were resorted to by the persons interested, they would meet with many obstacles and all dealings had to conform to the rules of the Bourse. Mr. Mirissi supported Mr. Rossano and said that supposing their clients came to them with the shares in their hands after the time proposed, what could they do? The question of the founders shares must be settled now. Mr. Nahman said that Arditi had given up nearly 3,000 founders shares and that these shares would probably afterwards come into the possession of the Association. It would, he said, be interesting to ascertain who were the real losers. Mr. Mirissi said that everybody naturally was trying to do the best for their own interests. Maitre Mercinier after some discussion said that the question was of settling the differences and the original subscribers would keep their shares. A person said that the original subscribers in some cases could not keep their shares, as in certain cases the bank would insist on delivery of the shares due to them. Maitre Mercinier answered that the scheme would apply to all, banks as well. If the proposal was adopted it would be beneficial. Brokers could not be made bankrupt as they were protected by the decision of the association, and that the project must be adopted in view of the intense crisis now existing. If the parties interested went to law with their brokers, the latter could not be declared insolvent. It was a question for the law to decide, and either party could gain the day in the law courts. The dealings in this Company's shares were abnormal. As transactions in the shares had taken place before the shares arrived, the settlement could be postponedindefinitely by the directors of the Company. The Company had made a proposal, if the parties interested did not care to accept it, they could go to law. But, he said, an arrangement, even a bad one, was better than a long lawsuit. The scheme' proposed was loyal, honest, and salutary and he advised the brokers to tell their clients that they did not refuse to settle, but only wanted to follow the regulations, After further observation by Mr. Gessarian, Mr. Nahman, etc., the Chairman proposed that the dissentients should raise their hands. Some isolated individuals did so and at the same time energetically protested against the scheme, but the majority being in favour of it, the Chairman declared the project carried.
All the interest this morning in the Bourse was concentrated on this meeting and transactions were very few.

div.head:
AN HOTEL MYSTERY.
THE DEATH OF VIVANTE
div.p: MURDER OR SUICIDE ?

The mysterious death of Vivante, who was found lying dead against a bed-pos in a room of an Alexandrian hotel is the subject of comment throughout the city Vivante entered the hotel at half past on on Friday morning in company with his cousin, Nacamuli. The bowab saw both mer enter and Vivante and Nacamuli went to the room of the former, where the latte remained for a quarter of an hour befort going to bed. During the night Nacamul heard no noise, but this fact is of ni account as his room was at the other end of the hotel. About three o'clock a jewelle who had taken a room at the hotel next to Vivante's heard a noise like the falling of a body, and at the same time he heard a shriek Being disturbed by the noise he listenec for a moment, but hearing nothing furthe he paid no more attention
Up to five o'clock in the morning no one else left the hotel, but at that time the boal noticed a young, fair man, of medium stature go out, who had taken a room the night before

About 8.10 a.m. the servant attending Vivante called him, but receiving no answer, he opened the door, which the deceased never locked on account of his being very asthmatic, and found Vivante at the foot of his bed with a rope round his neck. The room was not disarranged in the slightest degree, every. thing was in order, and there was no trace of toul play have taken place.

The rope which was found round the de ceased's neck had no knot in it but was drawn very tight, and his head was hanging down over his chest. The rope was of the thickness of a little finger and about two metres long.

Vivante was a regular visitor to the hotel in which this sad event took place, and on this occasion he only engaged his room on his arrival from Cairo on the 8th, inst. On the afternoon of the 11th inst. he played dominoes at the Bourse Café, as was his custom, and in the evening he took supper with Elia Coneegliano. He was in excellent spirits and told Mr. Conegliano that on the following day he was going to sell some of the shares which he held. Afterwards he went to the hotel with Nacamuli.
The deceased was the representative of the Remington Typewriter Company and of the automatic machines placed in the bars, and leaves some £10,000. He was 47 years of age.
The question which everybody, including the police, are asking is : was it murder or suicide ?

The police as yet have no clue to enable them to take decisive steps, and we can only add that the only information we have been able to gather is that one of his employés, a certain Arunson, is said to have threatened to strangle him. If it is case a murder, it is certain that it was not for theft, as money was found in the deceased's pocket, as well as his gold watch.

div.head: · PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: On Saturday week the Princess of Wales visited the Leicester Galleries and inspected the exhibition of water-colours of Egypt by Mr. Walter Tyndale.
Prince Aziz Pasha Hassan returned to Alexandria yesterday from Constantinople by the Khedivial Mail S.S. "Osmanieh."
Lord Cromer is staying at Bad Nauheim, at the Hôtel Auguste Victoria, where the Duke and Duchess of Portland have also arirved.
The Sultan has conferred the Grand Order of the Medjidiel on Hussein Fakhry Pasha, Minister of Public Works.
Sir Joseph Saba Pasha, K. C. M. G., is at present at Bad-Gastein (Austria), for the cure, and will remain there till the end of July.
Three months' leave of absence has been granted to Mr. Bernardi, Khedivial Legal Adviser, from the 20th inst.

Capt. Poole, Assistant Director of Intelligence, left Khartoum last Saturday for Egypt and Europe on leave. After the expiration of his leave he will remain in Cairo, and Kaim Amery Bey will return to Khartoum.

The governing body of the Battersea Polytechnic have appointed Mr. S.G. Rawson, D.Sc. (London), F.I.C., Principal of the Polytechnic, in succession to Mr. Sidney H Wells, who is resigning to take up the position o Director-General of the Department of Agriculture and Technical Education, for Egypt.

The marriage arranged between Captain A. E. Fitz-Gerald, second son of the late R. A. Fitz-Gerald Esq., and attached to the Egyptian Army, and Eleanor, daughter of Colonel Irwin, of Lynchow, Carlisle, will take place on the 7th of August at Arthurst Church, Longtown, Cumberland.
Mr. Littlewood, chief veterinary surgeon to the Egyptian Government, is leaving for England shortly on a six weeks' holiday

div.head: CAMEL CORPS DISASTER
div.p: THE COURT'S ENQUIRIES
CUASES OF DISASTER

With reference to the recent disaster to a party of the Camel Corps when l aving Bir Natron post, the "Sudan Times" is officially informed that a Court of Enquiry has recently been held at Dongola to investigate the circumstances connected with the incident.

The fact that a Court of Enquiry was held does not imply that there were any particular circumstances connected with the case which demanded an enguiry, but the court of enquiry was held according to the usual custom in order that a complete resume of the facts of the case might be obtained for the information of the military authorities, to enable them to judge if the disaster was attributable to any negligence on the part of those concerned or if it was dae to misfortune.
The disaster is officially said to be attributable to the following causes :
(1) The lack of water aggravated by the exceptionally intense heat. -
(2) The faot of an expert guide losing his way unaccountably on a road frequently traversed by him previously.
(3) The breakdown of a convoy of supplies which had left Debba in ample time to have reached Bir Natron before the garrison there could have begun to find themselves running short of supplies.
The report sent in by the court of enquiry is now under consideration by the authorities and a further statement will be made in due conrse.

div.head: RADICALS AND LORD CROMER.
div.p: The advanced section of the Radical party have been much exercised in their minds regarding the proposed national grant to Lord Cromer in recognition of his magnificent services to Egypt and the Empire, and a meeting was held at the House of Commons on Monday week, presided over by Mr. R. C. Lehmann, to discuss the matter. There was much difference of opinion on the subject of opposing the grant, it being held by some members that a monetary reward to a servant of the State for the discharge of his duty was contrary to public policy; but others urged that an exception should be made in the case of Lord Cromer, in view of his unique record. Ultimately the subject was allowed to drop without any decision being arrived at in respect of concerted action in the Honse.
The "Globe" commenting on this meeting remarks :

It is satisfactory to note that there has been a divergence of opinion among the antipatriots in the House of Commons, as to the action to be taken with regard to the proposed grant to Lord Cromer. We are quite ready to admit that the several members of Parliament who met together yesterday to discuss the matter are actuated by no personal animosity towards the late Consul-General. What is very appar. rent, however, is that the opportunity is regarded as an excellent one upon which to raise the whole question of Egyptian administration, and, of course, to find fault with the system of government in operation. And herein lies the danger of the situation. Had these political iconoclasts merely conspired to attack Lord Cromer himself, their action would have passed unnoticed. When, however, they range themselves alongside Egyptian agitators, fuel is added to the smouldering elements of disaffection. Not many months ago, as Lord Cromer stated in his annual report, there was cause for considerable un easiness, in official quartiers, as regards natiye unrest. By a firm hand, however, and a proper application of the law, the movement was suppressed, and quiet has reigned over since. The fact' was, those responsible for the agitation discovered that there was no responsive echo in England. Now, however, they will take heart again, and should a debate be raised in Parliament, and those responsible for it indulge in the usual condemnatory language of everything that is Bratish, the Egyptian agitator will recommence his campaign. Fortunately, there are still a few men on the Radical benches who realise and appreciate the advantages of our role in Egypt, as also in other parts of the world. The result of the debate, therefore, will only be to encourage native discontent at the expense of a more rigorous execution of the law..

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman liner "Fabian" sailed hence last Saturday evening for Liverpool direct with a general cargo, including 3797 Bales of Cotton.
The Ellerman liner " Flavian" arrived last evening from Liverpool, Gibraltar, Malta and Tripoli with a general cargo and sheep.

div.head: QUATORZE JUILLET
div.p: ALEXANDRIA'S CELEBRATION:

The celebration of the foundation of La République Française was marred in Alex adria to a great extent on account of their being no official organisation of a fête, but nevertheless yesterday was generally recognised in Alexandria as a day of celebration. The buildings of the main streets were gaily paroisés with bunting, in which the tricolour naturally predominated, but all of the many nations who find homes for their sons in Egypt were well represented. In the evening there was a feeble effort at illumination, but for this we can only give credit to the French Consulate, Cercle Français, Crédit Lyonnais, and Comptoir National d'Escompte.
The fête at San Stefano Casino on Saturday evening was a great success.

Yesterday evening special, performances were given at the Tour Eiffel and the Eldo rado, and both music-halls were well filled with enthusiastic audiences. At the Tour Eiffel an excellent and varied programine was provided and every turn was received with loud outbursts of applause, especially those of the English performers, whom we are glad to recoga nise as among the best artistes on the stage. Bert Flatt, the humorous American musical comedian scored a huge success, and both Violet Esdaile and the three Sisters Florence were most warmly received, while Annie Grey, who opened the programme to a somewhat thin audience was more heartily applauded than ever. At the conclusion of the performance the Marseillaise was sung by the whole troupe and the enthusiasm of the audience was unbounded. At the first notes of this soul-stirring national hymn the cosmopolitan audience rose to its feet, and, awaiting the chorus, joined in with a hearty good will. At the end of the second verse the strains of "God save the King" evoked a strong combination of voices from the many EngJishmen present, and was sung with a verve which delighted the hearts of those severed from their Motherland, while the shouts of "L'Entente Cordiale" which followed amply exemplified the genuineness of Anglo-French friendship. The last verse of the Marseillaise followed this, and the band then played the Italian national anthem, and the chorns of the Marseillaise was then repeated, the Khedivial national anthem being also given. Needless to say the audience unanimously and vociferously demanded an encore, and this was given, the Marseillaise being repeated without interlude. A similar scene was enacted at the Eldorado, to which extra attraction was given by the illuminated garden, the presence of four bands, and a lavish display of fireworks.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.p: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions expressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit o fair play to all, to permit-within certnin necessary limitsfree discussion.

div.head: THE ANTIQUITIES DEPARTMENT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Sir.- We residents in the Muallaqa buildAngs, Old Cairo, beg you to devote a space in your daily paper for the following: -

Some time ago, the Antiquities Department, in order to discover the door of the Tower of the Old Citadel, called Kasr esh-Shama or ElMuallaqa Fortress, made some diggings close by the buildings neighbouring the Muallaqa. A great pit was thereby created which was filled by infiltration water of a stagnant and offensive nature, as may render the place a source of deadly epidemics during the four seasons. The case having been submitted to the Public Health Department, it was suggested by it that the Antiquities Department which is most interested in the place, should pump out the water, of which it may profit at the same time by using it in watering a plot of ground adjacent to the place, some half an acre in area, and attempting to make a small garden of it.

The suggestion was however allowed to drop and a less expensive plan was recurred to by the Antiquities Department. The plan consisted in throwing a cantar of lime in the pic every month for killing mosquitoes. Advisable as the plan may appear, it has its drawbacks, as it will certainly deface the scenery and make the place less attractive to tourists and visitors, who flock in hundreds every year to visit the place. We, therefore, request you to join us in taking the cause of one of the best ruins in Egypt and enjoin on the Antiquities Department to adopt the plan proposed by the Sanitary Department, to which allusion has been made above.
We have the honour to be,
Sir,
Your obedient servants.
The Teachers Mollaca School :
Fouad Tadrus, Hanna Shattas, A. M. Fathi, B. K. Boutros, A. Shinoud.

div.head:
THE EGYPTIAN GOVERNMENT.
MINISTERIAL CHANGES.
div.p: NATIVE PRESS OPINION.
The forthcoming changes in the official world, which it is believed will take place in the autumn are the subject of as much comment in the Native, as in the Emopean Press. "Al Lewa" remarks :

The changes expected to take place in the present Government are now the important topic of conversation in every native circle. The position of the Council of Ministers will be vacant, for H.E. Mustapha Pasha Fahmy has resolved to tender his resignation con account of a ngw change of circumstances which does not permit his policy to continue as it is. It is said that H. E. was going to present his resignation before leaving for Europe, but it was decided that this resolution onght to be delayed and that Saad Pasha Zaglool the son-in-law of Moustafa Fahmy Pasha should go to London to have himself nominated for the premiership and to use Lord Cromer as an intercessor for him. But the latest news from England indicates that Saad Pasha's efforts have proved unsuiccessful. The information we have atout the new ministry indicates that two or three Ministers will resign and be replaced by two or three from the bar. We are now in a position to state that the new ministry will be practically responsible for its actions and the advisers will be advisers in the real sense of the word. The anthority of the provincial inspectors will then shrink and not exceed the bounds of simple superin tendence instead of actual interference with the duties of the mudirs who will be enti tled to a wider sphere of authority. The jurisdiction of the Provincial institutions will he extended. When these changes take place they will doubtless reyolutionise the present system of Government to the advantage of the Egyptians.
A Coptic vernacular newspaper of Cairo comments as follows on the rumours of the impending changes :

Great hopes are now evidently entertained by the Opposition party on the subject of the Egyptian Ministry. Theseindefatigableagitatora are under the impression that Sir Eldon Gorst carries in his pocket to England elaborate plans for a complete change in the presen order of things with the formation of a ney Ministry at the top of the list. Of course, the wish is in this case father to the thought, fo our Nationalists have always expressed a desire to see the present Administration overthrow and have been hammering on this copic fo over a decade. Their bête noire is the venerabl gentleman who has acted as Prime Minister i Egypt so long and is expected to relinqois the reins of office from day to day, owing to th delicate condition of his health. The enemie of our honest and cultured Premier seem t think that once he is out of the way the whol Government of Egypt will be remodelled on different plan and every object of the Nation alist agitators will be attained. The other Ministers are equally obnoxious to sedition mongers; their fall will be an additional pleasure no doubt. But if they happen to remain unde a new Premier selected from the other camp the triump of sedition will be considered complete for some time.

No doubt Moustafa Pasha Fahmy will retir one day and the present Ministry will b changed. But we assure our shrieking oppo nents that no Minister under the presen regime will find it possible or expedient t deviate from the course of the present Admin istration, ard that the will of the rulin Power "shall prevail" as long as its rule lasts.

div.head: MINISTRY OF PUBLIC INSTRUCTION.
div.p: A number of new officials are to be engaged this summer for the Ministry of Public Instruction The following advertisements are appearing in the English newspapers on the subject :

Assistant-Masters wanted for Secondary Schools in Cairo and Alexandria, under the Ministry of Education, to teach (1) English, including History and Geography; or (2) Ma. thematics; or (3) Science (Experimental Physics and Chemistry). To enter on duties 1st October. About 400 boys in each School, mostly Mohammedans.

Candidates should not be less than 23 nor over 30 years of age, have a robust constitution, and have taken a University Degree in Honours. They must have experience as Teachers ; preference will be given to applicants who hold a Diploma in Teaching.
Initial salary, £295 per annum (£Eg. 24 per mensem). Allowance for passage out to Egypt. Teaching hours, on an average, tour daily, Fridays only excepted. Summer vacation not less than two months.

Applications, with full statement of qualifications, and accompanied by copies only of testimonials, to be sent-marked outside "Assistant-Masterships" - to A. H. SHARMAN, Esq., Easbourn, Whitby, Yorkshire, to whom Candidates may apply for further information.

Four resident assistant-mistresses wanted, to begin work in October, in the Abbas Girls' School, Cairo, and in the Sanieh Girls' School and Training College, Cairo, under the Ministry of Education. Abbas School consists of Primary Classes, attended by 125 girls, mainly Mohammedans. Sanieh School consists of Primary Classes, attended by 216 girls, mainly Mohammedans, to which is attached the Training College, with an attendance of 15 students. English Head-Mistresses. Candidates must hold a Diploma in Teaching, have experience as Teachers, be not less than 25 years of age, and have a robust constitution. They shonld take a special interest in the education and training of Oriental girls. For one of the vacant posts special training and experience as a Kindergarten Teacher is an essential qualification. Intial salary, £197 per annum (£E. 16 per mensem), with furnished quarters. Allowance for passage out to Egypt. Summer vacation not less than two months. Teaching hours, on a average, four daily, Fridays only excepted.

Applications, with full statement of qualifications, and accompanied by copies only of testimonials, should be sent, not later than July 13th, to Miss Johnstone, care of the Rev. R.A. Ram, Mepal Rectory, near Ely, Cambridgeshire,' to whom Candidates may apply for further information.

div.head: Egyptian State Railways & Telegraphs.
div.p: NOTICE.

Tne Administration has the hononr to inform the public that tenders will be received up to noon on the 28th August 1907 for the supply of Sundry Articles, such as feather | Dusters, Sponges, Shovels, Hammers, Zinc, | Tin, Pig Lead etc., according to the Specification and List, of which copy can be obtained against payment of 200 millièmes, at the Central Office of the General Stores, Boulac (Cairo) and at the Office of the Inspector of Stores Gabbary (Alexandria), where the standard samples and drawings may also be inspected daily from 9 a.m. to 1 p.m., Sundays and holidays excepted. | All persons desiring to take part in this adjudication must submit the samples requested in the above mentioned list, and must previously lodge in the Central Treasury of the Administration a sum of L.E. 25 Twenty Five Egyptian Pounds) as a provision. al deposit; the successful tenderer must increase this sum to the amount of ten per of his accepted offer. ! Tenders must be accompanied by a stamped paper of the value of thirty milliemes, and also the receipt for the aforesaid provisional deposit. They should be addressed by registered post to :The General Manager, Egyptian State Railways,
· CAIRO, in double envelopes, the inner bearing the following inscription, "TENDER FOR THE SUPPLY OF
SUNDRY ARTICLES." All Tenders received later than the day and hour above mentioned will not be taken into consideration.
The Administration is not bound to accept the lowest or any offer, and reserves to itself the right to divide the order. Cairo, July 4th 1907.

div.head: AVIS
div.p: L'Administration a l'honneur de porter à la connaissance du public qu'elle recevra jusqu'au 28 Août 1907 à midi au plus tard, de offres pour la fourniture de divers articles tels que plumea:2x, éponges, pelles, marteaux, zinc, fer blanc, plomb en saumon, etc., suivant les Conditions du Cahier des charges et la liste dont on peut obtenir un exemplaire, contre paiement de 300 millèmes, au Bureau Central des Magasins Généraux à Boulac(Caire) et au Bureau de Mr. l'Inspecteur des Magasins de Gabbary (Alexandrie) chaque jour de neuf heures du matin à 1 h. p.m. les diman ches et jours fériés exceptés ; on peut également y examiner les échantillons types et dessins.

Toute personne désirant prendre part à cette adjudication doit présenter avec son offre les échantillons demandés dans la liste qui est annexée au Cahier des Charges et doit déposer, au préalable, dans la Caisse Centrale de l'Administration, une somme de L. E. 25 (Vingt-cinq Livres Egyptiennes) à titre de cautionnement provisoire. Le soumissionnaire déclaré adjudicataire devra parfaire cette somme jusqu'à concurrence du dix pour cent du montant de l'offre agréée.

Les offres devront être accompagnées d'une feuille de papier timbré de 30 (trente) millièmes ainsi que du reçu du versement du cautionnement provisoire. Elles seront adres. sées par la poste sous pli recommandé à:Monsieur le Directeur Général
des Chemins de Fer de l'Etat, Caire. et sous double enveloppe, l'intérieure portant la suscription suivante :
"Offre pour foarnitore d'articles divers."
Toute offre faite ou déposée postérieure ment au jour et à l'heure ci-dessus désignés ne sera pas prise en considération.
L'Administration ne s'engage pas à accepter l'offre la plus basse, ni à donner suite aux soumissions présentées. Elle se réserve le droi de diviser la commande. 30595-2-2. Le Caire le 4 Jnillet 1907

div.head:
FRANCE AND ITALY.
GARIBALDI STATUE UNVEILED.
AFFIRMATION OF FRIENDSHIP.

div.p: Speaking at the unveiling of a statue to Garibaldi here, M. Pichon said that, thanks to Garibaldi, France and Italy can to-day solemnly affirm a friendship which was the outcome of common memories. A misunderstanding between the two countries would be a deplorable error.
(Reuter
Messrs. Failières, Clemenceau, and Picbon, and General Picquart assisted at the unveiling of Garibaldi's statue. M. Pichon emphasized in his speech the necessity of Franco-Italian friendship.
(Havas)

div.head:
FRENCH NATIONAL FETE.
EXCITEMENT IN PARIS.

div.p: The review of the troops was most brilliant.
The manoeuvres of the balloon "Patrie" above the Hippodrome were greatly admired.

(At the moment when the presidential cortège, returning to the Elysée, passed into the Avenue Marigny, Maillet, an "inscrit maritime" from Rouen, fired two revolver shots into the air. He was arrested and declared that he wanted to attract attention. He is believed to be insane.
(Havas)

M. Fallières was returning from to-day's review at Longchamps when a man fired two shots from a revolver at the procession in Avenue Marigny. Nobody was hurt. The man was arrested. He is believed to be mad.
(Later). There is no doubt that the man who fired at the procession was a maniac. He fired in the air.
(Reuter)

div.head:
DECLARATION OF WAR.
PROPOSALS AT THE HAGUE.

div.p: The sub-committee has adopted, with two abstentions, the French proposal regarding a declaration of war. The reservations made by Great Britain, United States. and Japan have been withdrawn and the Dutch amendment rejected. Other amendments providing for a state of war not to commence for neutrals till, say, 48 hours after the declaration are under discussion. The Chinese delegate urged the necessity of defining war, as war was sometimes made on China under the name of an expedition.
(Reuter)

div.head:
KOREA AND JAPAN.
PROTEST TO MR CHOATE.

div.p: The Korean deputation yesterday presented to Mr. Choate their protest against Japan. Mr. Choate, while dwelling on the goodwill of the United States for Korea, said that if she wished to make representations she should address Washington.
(Reuter)

div.head:
CARDIFF EN FETE.
KING OPENS NEW DOCK.

div.p: The King and Queen have arrived. (Renter)
The King and Queen opened the new dock here. The town is en fête. Their Majesties received a magnificent welcome. (Reuter)

div.head:
ANOTHER RAND OUTRAGE.
BOKSBURG HOTEL BLOWN UP.

div.p: Another Rand outrage occurred yesterday. A hotel was blown up by dynamite at Boksburg. Three persons were killed and several injured.
(Reuter)

div.head:
THE KIEFF MUTINEERS.
NINETY EIGHT SENTENCED.

div.p: Six of the Kieff mutineers have been sentenced to death, 12 to penal servitude for life, and 80 others to lesser sentences. B (R.)

div.head:
GREEKS IN AMERICA.
ILL-TREATMENT OF AN AMERICAN.

div.p: At Roanoke (Virginia) a mob, seeking to avenge ill-treatment of an American in a Greek restaurant, wrecked every Greek place in the city. They also attacked Syrian stores. Many arrests have been made.
(Reuter)

div.head:
RUSSIAN GENERALS INDICTED
FALSE REPORTS OF BATTLES.

div.p: A document published here indicts Generals Stoessel, Fock, Smirnoff, and Reuss with charges of concocting false reports of battles and recommending defeated generals for decorations. All are capital offences. (Reuter)

div.head:
A KOREAN HAREM.
CONCEALMENT OF ASSASSINS.

div.p: 24 men have been discovered concealed in the ladies' apartments in the palace. It is | believed that they intended to assassinate the ministers.

div.head:
WORKING MASON KNIGHTED.
LORD MAYOR OF CARDIFF.

div.p: The King has knighted the Lord Mayor of Cardiff, who was a working inason. (R.)

div.head:
THE ELCHO SHIELD.
WON BY IRELAND.

div.p: Ireland has won the Elcho Shield. (Reuter)
The Khedive has arrived. (Havas)
The Sultan has deputed Shereef Wazan to use his influence with the mountain tribes to secure the release of Sir H. Maclean. (Reuter)
The Senate and Chamber of Deputies have passed the reserved clauses of the Wine Bill. The session has closed:
(Reuter)
The "Neue Freie Presse" learns from Rome that the Triplice, not having been denounced within the required time, continues until 1914. In politic circles it is remarked that this is
announced at the moment that Baron d'Aeren Esthal is on his way to meet Signor Tittoni. (H.)
M. Tittoni has received Baron d'Aerenthal.
(Hava 8
| Gloucester beat Kent by 96 runs. Surrey 3- beat South Africans by 85 runs. The match al between Lancashire and Sussex was drawn.
(Reuter

div.head: ORIENTAL AND EUROPEAN.
div.p: Sir Charles Elirt, alike by his long and waried diplomatic experience and his administration in East Africa, is a highly qualified Fudge of unfamiliar civilisations. Among the numerous works that have been devoted of recent years to the problems of the Far East, his unpretentious little book takes a very high place, and the reader of his letters will learn more from them than from nine-tenths of the more elaborate volumes on Japan and China which have been published of recent years. These letters were written in the summer and autumn of 1906, during a tour through Japan and the coast provinces of China "The main object of my journey," Sir Charles Eliot tells ns, "was to obtain some practical knowledge of the languages and creeds of the Far East, and, in particular, to study the curious development which Buddhism has undergone in those counEries." The result of these special investigations may be published at a later date. In the meantime, we have the advantage of looking on the much-discussed Far East through the eyes of a very shrewd, impartial, and catholicminded observer.

The most important truth which emerges from these pages is the fact which struck Sir Charles Eliot most forcibly during his trayels, _"the distinctness of China and Japan from the rest of Asia, and particularly from the Indian and Mohammedan East." We are too much inclined to speak of

"Asiatics" or "Orientals" in the same broad sense as that in which we speak of"Europeans," and so to ignore the fundamental distinctions between the East and West of Asia. Yet there is at least as much difference between a Hindu and a Japanese as there is between a Frenchman and an Arab, and to forget this fact is to be led upon a fatally erroneous path of argument. In his very able introduction, summing up the main features of his experience in the Far East, Sir Charles Eliot suggests that the civilisations of the world as now existing may be divided into four main types,-European (including the white races all over the earth), Mohammedan, Hindu, and Chinese. This is a far more rational division than the commoner one into European and Asiatic. The civilisation of the white races has the central fact of Christianity in common, and enjoys joint ownership of the great mechanical discoveries which have done so much in the last century to modify the facts of human life. Christianity, as Sir Charles Eliot reminds us, for all its Asiatic origin, must be regarded as an essentially European religion, for it has taken hold on humanity nowhere outside the confines of the white races. Our author doubts how far it is responsible for the material, scientific, and moral progress of Europe, point ing out that this has been least striking where the clergy have most power, as in Spain and Russia. Perhaps he has here failed to distinguish between Christianity and the Church, which are not at all the same thing. But the general unity of white civilisation is unquestionable. The civilisations of Westen | Asia, as far as the Chinese frontiers, are less questionably the outcome of the dominant religions, Mohammedanism and Hinduism. Neither of them is likely to have any extended future before it. Islam, though essentially proselytising, has been restrained within well-marked limits owing to our recognition of its dangers, as illustrated by the long struggle of Eastern Europe against the Turk and by the recent fight to save Egypt from Mahdism. Hinduism is not aggressive, and is practically confined to India. When we come to the Chinese sphere, includJing Japan, we are confronted with a new set of conditions, much more closely recalling those of Europe. Religion here has less to do with the dominant type of civilisation than in any other part of the world. "The basis of Chinese institutions is an excellent, sane, prosaic, moral philosophy," which can hardly be called a religion at all. Japan has nothing that can | be called a national religion, in the sense we which we speak of Britain as a Christian country. China and Japan are neither fanatical nor aggressive by natural tendency, though the trend of recent events has taught the leaders of both countries that their old policy of dignified conservatism and splendid isolation can only be preserved by force of arms. Japan recognised this fundamental truth in the last generation, and the thoroughness with which she has adapted herself to the new conditions is one of the most surprising facts in the history of the world. China is gradnally awakening to it, and the history of the next half-century in the Far East will probably be dominated by this recognition, in which Japan is likely to take a very important share. Si Charles Eliot has thus been led to the conclu sion-shared by most competent publiciststhat the Chinese and Japanese are destined to become one of the dominant Powers in the Pacific, and to be brought into acute rivalry with the other great world civilisation--the aggressive, esurient, and haughty civilisation of Europe. This probability is what the German Emperor and many other statesmen agree to name as the "yellow peril," against which it is often asserted that a league of Christendom must be formed It is worth while to quote the impressive passages in which Sir Charles Eliot gives the reasons for his refusal to join in thi outcry, since it is the keynote and the con clusion of his researches :

"I would not call this the Yellow Peril, for do not myself feel the danger. European civilisation is not, to my mind, so perfect tha any alteration or amalgamation with othe schemes of life would degrade it, or tha humanity would be a loser if it does not be come paramount in all parts of the globe. No • Letters from the Far East. By Sir Charles Elio London : E. Arnold. [8s, 6d, net.] one possesses the necessary impartiality and cosmopolitan outlook to be able to decide whether the Asiatic or the European character is, as a whole, the better. It is, however, just to say that the greatest achievements of Europeans in art and literature are superior to the greatest achievements of Asiatics in the same spheres ; but, then, these achievements are far from being a general characteristic of Europeans. The productive periods are few, widely. scattered in time, and confined to few countries. On the other hand, the evils and ugliness of modern European civilisation are as obvious as its disadvantages, and there is no clearer proof of them than the fascination which the East exercises upon nearly all who come under its spell. The extension of European influence does not mean the distribution over other continents of the beauty and genius of Europe, but merely of the most commonplace aspects of European life and industry. To those who are occupied with the task of organising new cities and states colonial life may seem the most interesting in the world-and I have felt the passion myself in East Africa---but for those who do not share in this creative joy, and look simply at the results, it must be confessed that America, particularly Western America, and the British colonies have added very little to the art, literature, interest, variety and pleasure of humanity ; nor do I see why it should be considered a calamity if European influence does not become everywhere predominant or even has to recede in certain spheres. Variety must be for the intellectual and pictorial advantage of mankind as long as the various types are not destructive or evil in themselves. I should be sorry to see the strength and extent of Mohamedanism increased, for it is an intolerant and destructive religion, which with difficulty frees itself from such evils as slavery. Yet much will be lost to the worldnay, is being lost-with the gradual disappearance of Mohamedan states. But Far Easter, and specially Japanese, civilisation can be reproached with no particular evil, and it brings with it a picturesqueness, cheerfulness, and courtesy which must be recognised as good elements. Its fault is not aggressiveness, but rather a too great willingness to learn, which makes it ready to abandon its own good points."

div.head: SEXTUPLETS.
div.p: The " Globe," says :

A correspondent has received from West Africa & remarkable photograph from the hinterland of Accra of a native woman and six children, all born at a birth. The fact is, we believe, authentically established, and must be, we should imagine, without, a parallel. Un former times, such an event would have been deemed a portent of the most terrible kind, presaging war, famine, and pestilence, but we daresay that even on the Gold Coast it will at this time of day be received with comparative equanimity.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY
div.p: CRICKET. RAILWAY INSTITUTE

p.hi: versus 3RD COLDSTREAM GUARDS. The second meeting of these clubs took place at Guezireh Badrane last Friday. The Institute were unable to place a full team into the field but the coldstreams were at full strength. The Guards skipper having won the toss sent in Sergts. Smith and Sohrstadt but the former was out 1.b.w. second ball. Major the Earl of Lanesborough the next man was missed off the two first talls he received. He only scored five, however, before being taken nicely in the long field by Wilson. On Private Revell joining Mohrstadt runs came fairly fast, Revell inaking some splendid "carpet" drives. When 20 Mohrstadt was clean bowled by Revd. Burns, Lieut. Tollemache who jollowed was also bowled by Revd. Burns for the unenviable "duck." White kept in while Revell scored a few but was finally caught brilliantly by Windsor, Capt. Lane and Lieut. Burton the two next men were both bowled by Revd. Barns for "ducks." Revell was the next man to go after a splendid innings of 32. His dismissal was a curious one. He played forward to a fast ball from Wilson and a confident appeal was inade for a catch at the wicket which the umpire refused. The batsman under the impression that he had struck the ball and not hearing the umpire's decision commenced to retire but was told to go back, but before he could return to his crease Davies had whipped the bails off. None of the other batsman did much and the innings closed for 74.P.G. Windsor and Revd. Burus opened the Institute innings and so brilliantly did both men play that the Guards total was passed before both were out. Windsor who made 42 made some magnificent strokes, one huge drive going right out of the ground. He made some splendid cuts and he deserved the ovation he received on coming in. Rev. Burns who made 26 batted very well indeed. Wilson subsequently batted well for 20 and on the fall of the eighth wicket stumps were drawn, the Institute reversing the result of the previous match. Rev. Burns deserves special praise for his bowling. He made a record by capturing 9 wickets for 36 runs. Appended are the scores :

div.head: AVIS
div.p: La Municipalité met en adjudication les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs au sud de l'ancien cimetière israélite jusqu'au fort el Nahas.
Le cautionnement est fixé à LE. 15.
Le cahier des charges est déposé an Bureau de la Voirie où il peut-être consulté par les intéressés tous les jours de 9 h. à midi, les jours fériés exceptés.
Les offres devront être adressées sous pli cacheté à Monsieur l'Administrateur de la Municipalité avant le 18 courant.
Elles pourront également être déposées en séance de la Délégation la même jour à 5h.p.m.
L'enveloppe devra porter en outre la mention: "Soumission pour les travaux de prolongement de la rue des Parcs."

Le cautionnement ou le reçu d'une banque, d'après les conditions du cahier des charges, devra être remis séparément au Service de la Comptabilité Générale avant l'ouverture des offres et au plus tard le 18 courant à midi.
Toute offre qui ne remplit pas les conditions ci-dessus sera écartée.
L'Administrateur.
(signé) W.P. Chataway.
Alexandrie, le 7 juillet 1905.
